paper_abstract: We show that polynomial time randomness of a real number does not depend on the choice of a base for representing it. Our main tool is an 'almost Lipschitz' condition that we show for the cumulative distribution function associated to martingales with the savings property. Based on a result of Schnorr, we prove that for any base r, n.log(2) n-randomness in base r implies normality in base r, and that n (4)-randomness in base r implies absolute normality. Our methods yield a construction of an absolutely normal real number which is computable in polynomial time.
paper_title: Feasible Analysis, Randomness, and Base Invariance
